title: Dejay Rawiri Kane killed Emma Bagley after speeding at 121km/h in 50km zone in Windsor, New Zealand
text:
Emma Bagley (pictured), 37, was in the car with her husband and two kids when her vehicle was T-boned by Dejay Rawiri Kane

A driver who was speeding at 121km/h in a 50km/h zone has been jailed over the horrific smash that killed a nurse.

Dejay Rawiri Kane was three times above the legal alcohol limit when his vehicle T-boned Emma Bagley's car, in Windsor, New Zealand, on December 7, 2018.

The 20-year-old's license was already disqualified at the time of the crash.

Before the fatal crash that killed Ms Bagley, 37, witnesses reported that Kane was speeding down the wrong side of the road and weaving in-and-out of cars.

He was later seen purchasing alcohol and downing it before heading out onto the streets.

Kane continued speeding when his car smashed into Ms Bagley's car, who was with her husband and two young children at the time.

Ms Bagley was rushed to hospital where she underwent surgery but died due to the severity of her injuries.

Her husband was also placed in an induced coma following extensive surgeries, and was later transferred to another hospital.

Kane's blood was found to have 155mg, plus or minus seven milligrams, of alcohol per 100ml of blood in his system, NZ Herald reported.

Kane appeared at the High Court at Invercargill (pictured), on Tuesday, and broke down after he was sentenced to four years and eight months' prison

Kane appeared at the High Court at Invercargill, on Tuesday, and broke down after he was sentenced to four years and eight months' prison.

He had previously pleaded guilty to one charge of manslaughter and four charges of reckless driving causing injury.

Ms Bagley's father also appeared in court and read a victim impact statement, explaining that telling his grandkids that their mother was dead 'was the most challenging thing the family had ever gone through', the publication reported.
description: Dejay Rawiri Kane was three times above the legal alcohol limit when his vehicle T-boned Emma Bagley's car, in Windsor, New Zealand, on December 7, 2018.
authors: Sahar Mourad For Daily Mail Australia
